_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

Examples of how the teaching is visible: A mendicant who sees a sight with their eyes
A mendicant who hears a sound with their ears
A mendicant who smells an odor with their nose
A mendicant who tastes a flavor with their tongue
A mendicant who touches a tangible with their body
A mendicant who knows a thought with their mind
The experience of the mendicant in each: They experience both the sight and the desire for the sight
They experience both the sound and the desire for the sound
They experience both the odor and the desire for the odor
They experience both the flavor and the desire for the flavor
They experience both the tangible and the desire for the tangible
They experience both the thought and the desire for the thought
The absence of desire in the mendicant i: They experience the sight but no desire for the sight
They experience the sound but no desire for the sound
They experience the odor but no desire for the odor
They experience the flavor but no desire for the flavor
They experience the tangible but no desire for the tangible
They experience the thought but no desire for the thought
